Update: Last week, at an economic forum in St. Petersburg, Putin commented on the lack of development in the START negotiations. Arguing that Russia has been pushing for the nuclear arms treaty talks to begin, the US, in contrast, have been stalling and made no moves to move negotiations along. Consequently, Putin said that Russia will just not extent the treaty, if the US is not interested in beginning talks. Putin speaking so bluntly on the topic seems to underline Russia's dwindling desire to pursue these negotiations. In combination with recent remarks on Russia's arms production abilities, Putin seems to be emphasizing Russia's position as a leading military power and as such, a country that does not need treaties. Just around the same time, leading democrats send a letter to Trump urging him to engage with negotiations and seek an extension on the START treaty, as they feared the potential consequences of a lack of treaty. Trump has not responded this query, and does not seem interested in prioritizing this issue. This current situation seems a long way away from any formal negotiations to commence, and I adjust my forecast accordingly. Update (9/06/19) In my frst forecast, I adopted a rational approach to the possibilities US and Russia have in the renewal/non renewal of an arms control treaty. In this update I decided to drastically change my approach as well as my forecast, considering mainly two articles I recently happened to read (https://www.brookings.edu/blog/order-from-chaos/2019/04/25/nuclear-security-arms-control-and-the-us-russia-relationship/ and https://www.rferl.org/a/putin-says-russia-prepared-to-drop-arms-control-treaty-if-u-s-not-interested-in-renewal/29984790.html). First of all, looking at the history of the arms control treaty between the two superpowers, it is noticeable how the first efforts generally begun from the US part, followed by a Russian side showing less interest in drafting a treaty to enhance their bargaining power. Apparently with the Trump administration, which will most likely still stand in October, thearm control barganining changed: the US are showing less interest in re-arranging the situation, even if facing the incoming end of the New START. Putin obviously can't show weakness, instead he has to show diplomatic muscles by saying that Russian security can be assured even without an arm control treaty. At this point it is not very likely that Trump and Putin will show signs of backstepping from their positions - thsi consideration relies purely from the consideration of the leaders' personality and constructed role in international politics. Moreover, "U.S. and Russian officials in the past have held strategic stability talks to take a broad look at developments that affect their strategic relationship. Such talks are useful, particularly when new developments, such as those in the cyber and space domains, emerge and when Russian nuclear doctrine has provoked concern in Washington and led to changes in the U.S. nuclear posture. Even if strategic stability talks do not spin off specific negotiations, they provide a venue for the sides to exchange views and better understand the concerns of the other. During the Trump administration, a one-day session of strategic stability talks took place in September 2017. As of March 2019, it has not agreed to a second meeting". If a new treaty or the extension of the New Start will happen, it will probably happen with the new US administration. In a few months I will know if my previous approach would have been more accurate than this new one. I think this one relies more on the diplomatic history in arms control between US and Russia, but the psychological and contextual variables can be unpredictable.

Trump has a tendency to pull out of Obama negotiated deals but is never eager to renegotiate them, i.e. the Iran Nuclear deal and Paris Climate accords. Pulling out of the INF could've been a way to increase pressure to bring Russia to the table and increase the US's bargaining position. However, neither side yet to show a willingness to renegotiate. Also I find it more than likely that Trump would prefer to let Obama's START deal lapse, rather than extend it, based on his previous handling of Obama deals and his criticism of START. If both side are keen to negotiate a new Nuclear deal then I predict it'll take more time for them to cool off over pulling out of the INF and then there will have to be months of maneuvering and signaling before talks can be made on when and where negotiation could happen. I find this to be a process that'll take longer than 6 months and therefore find it unlikely, but not impossible that formal nuclear negotiations could begin before October 1st 2019.

- There will be an extension/a new treaty I think that is very likely that Russia and the US will implement a new treaty or will introduce some modifications to the text because both of them they have recently increased their military capacity and updated their technologies. To be more clear, I compare the current New START to the previous one, the START treaty negotiated in the ‘80s. At that time the tensions between the two superpowers was higher than today, and so was the fear of the capabilities and intentions of the other: that treaty reflected the suspicion and the uncertainty of those years, including strict limits on nuclear proliferation. Instead, the New START has been stipulated in 2009 and “does not contain layers of limits and sublimits; each side can determine its own mix of land-based intercontinental ballistic missiles (ICBMs), submarine-launched ballistic missiles (SLBMs), and heavy bombers.”. It doesn’t forbid the states to modernize strategic nuclear forces, even if the goal of predictability and transparency of their intention is still present. This fact has allowed Russia and US to develop their offensive nuclear technologies, so will be necessary to modernize the treaty too. I would also add that Russia is currently in a bad economic situation, and I can’t imagine as a brilliant idea from Putin put himself in the position of raising the military expenditure in absence of an agreement with the US: this would mean more taxes and more dissatisfaction among the population. Another reason, is the necessity of an agreement between the two powerful state about army proliferation. Indeed, after reciprocal accusations about not respecting the INF, both the State withdraw from it. So, now it is fundamental keeping at least another agreement alive and concrete, both to avoid the risk of proliferation and to not damage even more the historically troubled relations between Russia and US. In addition, a renovation of this treaty would be an occasion to contrast the rise of China: indeed it has established a cooperation with European countries and is investing an impressive flow of money in infrastructure to control the markets in a not so far future (ex. The construction of BRI). In front of such a plan and because of the recent trade war that Trump has engaged with China, the US have better to keep Russia on its side at least in this field. In addition, I argue that China is also developing its nuclear arms, which could be interpreted in two ways: as the reason why continuing having bilateral agreement between Russia and US is useless, because other big countries instead are becoming more aggressive, or as the reason why is necessary at least maintaining the order and pursuing cooperation, also signing bilateral agreements like this or even include the “enemy” (China) in order to control it.

Base Rate for the forecast at hand are the decisions of the Trump administration to leave or formally re-negotiate international treaties and memberships in international organizations. Due to the high degree of uncertainty in terms of the current US administration’s international policies, and the discrepancy to former US government’s policies, the forecast excludes the time prior Trump’s election- even though there were already withdrawals prior, such as the US withdrawal from the Treaty on the Limitation of Missile Defence Systems (ABM Treaty). Following withdrawals were detected: On January 23, 2017, Trump signed an executive order to renegotiate NAFTA, with the intention of obtaining a more favorable deal for American workers. Eventually, Canada, Mexico and the US agreed upon on replacing NAFTA with the USMCA treaty on September 30, 2017 after formal renegotiations (http://www.wongfleming.com/trump-updates-2018-trumps-treatment-of-international-treaties-immigrants-and-refugees/). On January 23, 2017, Trump withdrew the US from the TPP Agreement, promoting closer economic cooperation between the signing states, without formal re-negotiations (Ibid.). On January 23, 2017, Trump formally abandoned the TTIP negations for a free transatlantic economic zone and declared an “end to the era of multinational trade agreements.” (Ibid.) In August 2017, Trump announced that the US would be withdrawing from the Paris Climate Agreement with the possibility of rejoining “if the terms improved for the United States.” Two formal negotiation sessions have taken place since then but only pro forma since the US cannot withdraw officially before three years after the agreement entered into force (Ibid.). On October 12, 2017, the US notified the UN's culture and education body, UNESCO of their. decision to withdraw from the organization and to seek to establish a permanent observer mission to UNESCO instead.
